In the present study, we project the ambient PM
centration in India by analysing 13 Coupled Model Inter-
comparison Project 5 (CMIP5) model data for two climate
change scenarios represented by representative concentration
pathways, RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, and combine with demographic
and socioeconomic projections used in the
economic pathway (SSP) scenarios as key scenario drivers
estimate future premature mortality burden for 10 combined
jected to drop below the baseline period exposure only after 2050
under the RCP4.5 and after 2090 under the RCP8.5 scenario.
Changes in meteorology induced by climate change are expected

rapidly in future. On the contrary, population is projected to

projected to increase further only for SSP3. All these factors are
uence the projected premature mortality burden
over India spatially and temporally. We hope that our results
might help steer policy to mitigate air pollution in future decades

cult to achieve and the RCP6 scenario lies
between RCP4.5 and RCP8.5. Therefore, RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 are
expected to provide a realistic range of the estimates in future.

future under the RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 scenarios. Ambient PM

for the baseline period. CMIP5 model derived PM
shows good agreement with satellite-derived PM
with a steeper slope and better (smaller intercept) agreement with
the RCP8.5 scenario. In terms of bias (Supplementary Fig. 1), the
ensemble of 13 CMIP5 models overestimates PM
of Rajasthan (marked by black box in Supplementary Fig. 1) and
some parts of north India and underestimates over the rest of
India as per projection under RCP4.5 scenario. Under the
